Take a look at the Center for State and Local Government Excellence web site, http://slge.org.   Lots of research and information on compensation, pensions, retirement plans, and health care.  Many places are making changes in benefits, especially for new employees.  You also can sign up to receive the Center's monthly e-news which covers workforce, compensation, and benefit issues.

Patrick both California State Association of California and the League of California Cities have issued whitepapers on the issue of retirement.  You might want to check with your local chapter of League of California Cities.  There has been some work done by city managers in various counties on the retirement issue.

author: Patrick Heisinger
text:
Hello all – as you know (especially where I live/work in California) the costs associated with the salaries and retirements of public employees have become a controversial topic.  My question is, are there current examples of jurisdictions trying to reform their compensation and retirement schedules because overtime they will become too expensive???  It appears many organizations are identifying this as an issue, but are any taking strategic steps to try and rectify the situation? 
I am very interested in the dynamic between the chief executive, unions, and the elected officials of the jurisdiction.  If somebody out there can point me to a place online that may have some articles or even staff reports on this or a similar topic I would really appreciate it!
Thank you 
Patrick
title: Reforming the salaries and retirements of public employees???
